claim.text: The average privately owned car in North America sits parked 95% of its life
claim.claim: Average privately owned car in North America is parked 95% of the time

results.summary: The 95% parked statistic is a widely cited figure originating from transportation research.
results.detail: This statistic originates from Donald Shoup's influential work on parking policy, particularly his book 'The High Cost of Free Parking' (2005, revised 2011). The figure has been cited by the RAC Foundation in the UK and various transportation researchers. Some studies cite slightly different figures (92-96%) depending on methodology, but 95% is the most commonly referenced approximation for private vehicle idle time.
sources: Donald Shoup, 'The High Cost of Free Parking' (2005)
Note: Unable to perform live web verification - based on training knowledge

claim.text: A household with two cars — common in any neighborhood without robust transit — dedicates 30 to 50 square meters of land to storing those vehicles
claim.claim: Two-car household dedicates 30-50 square meters to vehicle storage (driveway, garage, street frontage)

results.summary: Standard parking space dimensions support the 30-50 square meter range for two-car household vehicle storage.
results.detail: A standard parking space is approximately 2.4-2.7 meters wide by 4.8-5.5 meters long (approximately 12-15 square meters per space). Two spaces would require 24-30 square meters minimum. A two-car garage typically measures 5.5-6.0 meters wide by 5.5-6.0 meters deep (30-36 square meters). Adding driveway apron space (approximately 5-15 square meters for maneuvering), the 30-50 square meter range is consistent with standard residential parking provisions. This is based on common engineering standards for parking dimensions.
sources: Standard parking design guidelines (ITE Parking Generation, local zoning codes)
Engineering knowledge of typical garage and parking dimensions

claim.text: Their data shows that each shared vehicle replaces between four and eight privately owned cars
claim.claim: Mobility cooperative data shows each shared vehicle replaces 4-8 privately owned cars

results.summary: The 4-8 car replacement range is consistent with carsharing research, though specific figures vary by study and methodology.
results.detail: Multiple carsharing studies cite replacement ratios in this range. UC Berkeley's Transportation Sustainability Research Center has published research showing one carsharing vehicle can replace between 4-13 private vehicles depending on the market and methodology. The commonly cited figure from earlier North American studies was around 9-13 cars replaced, while European studies often show lower ratios of 4-8. The claim is directionally accurate but 'mobility cooperative data' is vague - different cooperatives and studies report different figures within and beyond this range.
sources: UC Berkeley Transportation Sustainability Research Center carsharing studies
Unable to verify specific current sources due to lack of web search access

claim.text: Bremen's stadtmobil network, operating since 1990, reports similar ratios in German cities
claim.claim: Bremen's stadtmobil network has been operating since 1990

results.summary: Unable to verify the 1990 founding date for Bremen's stadtmobil network due to lack of web search access.
results.detail: I was unable to search for evidence about stadtmobil Bremen's founding date due to tool permission restrictions. Car sharing in Germany did begin emerging in the late 1980s and early 1990s, making a 1990 date plausible, but I cannot confirm the specific founding year for Bremen's stadtmobil operation without access to primary sources. The claim requires verification from stadtmobil's official history or German car sharing historical records.
